conclusion: Analyze the velocity-time graph to understand how the particle's motion can lead to it passing through a certain position three times within the time interval from 0 to t1.
The graph is symmetric about the dashed line, indicating symmetric velocity changes around this line.
The graph shows velocity starts positive, decreases to zero, becomes negative, returns to zero, and becomes positive again.
Initially, the particle has a positive velocity, meaning it is moving in the positive direction.
As time progresses, the velocity decreases to zero, indicating the particle comes to a stop momentarily.
The velocity becomes negative, indicating the particle reverses direction and moves in the negative direction.
The velocity returns to zero again, indicating another momentary stop.
Finally, the velocity becomes positive again, indicating the particle moves in the positive direction once more.
When the particle's velocity is zero, it is at a turning point, happening twice within the interval.
The particle passes through a certain position three times: first moving in the positive direction, second reversing direction, and third changing direction again.
Scenario 1: The particle starts at a position, moves forward, stops, reverses direction, moves backward, stops again, and moves forward through the position once more.
Scenario 2: The particle could start at a different position but must pass through the same position three times due to symmetric velocity changes.

The particle starts moving in the positive direction, stops, reverses direction to move in the negative direction, stops again, and finally moves in the positive direction once more, passing through the same position three times.
